Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Carnivory in the Oligo-Miocene: Dietary community ecology and diversity dynamics of large mammalian predators
Award.AbstractNarration:
Competition is a common explanation for why carnivorous mammals differ in ecology, structure, and function. Over long time scales, it may also explain how current carnivore communities assembled. Dogs (wolves, jackals, foxes, coyotes, domestic dogs) originated in North America 40 million years ago but initially comprised primarily small raccoon-like forms. Although dogs later grew into one of the most diverse carnivore groups, they became large and carnivorous only in the Oligocene and Miocene epochs, 20 million years into their history - why? As the smaller early dogs lived alongside potentially large carnivore competitors - bears, bear-dogs, false saber-toothed cats, and weasels and allies - the North American Oligo-Miocene presents an ideal system to investigate how competition may have shaped, even suppressed, the initial diversification of a group.

Inferring competition in the fossil record is difficult and depends on reconstructing body size and diet from dental and skeletal remains. To do so, this project will use both linear measurements and dental complexity analysis, a new technique that quantifies tooth surfaces using geographic information systems measures. Dental complexity captures the texture of teeth adapted for different diets, ranging from herbivory to carnivory. Combined, these approaches allow the classification of extinct species into body size and dietary types. This can then be used to quantify the potential for competition between dogs and other carnivorous mammals throughout their early evolutionary history. Studying early dogs and their potential competitors will aid understanding of current carnivore communities at this time of accelerated global change.

POR.DRECONTENT:
What drives the success, failure, and coexistence of species? Is it better to be jack of all trades or master of one? And--given current ecological and environmental changes worldwide--have the answers to these questions been consistent over deep time?

The deep history preserved in the fossil record provides baselines for how intrinsic and extrinsic factors make species vulnerable to extinction in the absence of human effects. Therefore, Blaire Van Valkenburgh and Mairin Balisi investigated the above questions using the rich fossil record of North American dogs (Canidae, including domestic dogs, wolves, coyotes, and foxes). Currently, only eight species of dogs roam North America; but the ancestors of all dogs originated on this continent approximately 40 million years ago, producing a total of more than 130 species since then and demonstrating a compelling diversity of sizes and diets. They ranged from large dogs similar to living African hyenas, weighing 90 kg and crushing bone, to small dogs that fed mainly on fruit and other vegetation. Many species appeared to have coexisted in the same regions, in contrast to our impoverished ecosystems today. Understanding what came before us is crucial, especially as what remains with us--including large predators like gray wolves--continue to be threatened by anthropogenic effects.

Outcomes: Intellectual Merit

We discovered that dog species that mostly consumed meat and bone or mostly consumed only plants tended to persist for several million years shorter than those that were more generalized (omnivorous). However, this tendency had a minimal impact on the extinction risk of large predatory dogs, which was about the same as that of smaller non-predatory dogs. This was the case until the end of the last Ice Age about 10,000 years ago, when all dog species that went extinct were large and predatory. These extinctions drastically restructured North American ecosystems, with changes at the top of the food chain cascading to levels below, leaving smaller foxes and coyotes as the dominant type of dog in North America today.

In addition to the main project, Balisi studied an area in Central California that was habitat to four dog species between five and six million years ago. This area preserved fossilized dog feces, and these particular fossil feces contained bone fragments that belonged to an animal larger than the dog itself. This discovery is the first direct evidence of bone-eating behavior in an extinct dog. As bone-eating can facilitate the return of nutrients to soils, this discovery provides greater insight into food-web structure prior to the Ice Age extinctions.

These results highlight the intrinsic dangers of being an ecological specialist such as a large carnivore. By examining the fossil record alongside the modern record, we found that extrinsic factors unique to the end of the last Ice Age--such as human effects--appear to exacerbate these dangers. Our results therefore contribute not only to evolutionary studies but also to the burgeoning field of conservation paleobiology, which uses the fossil record to inform inferences about modern ecosystems.

Outcomes: Broader Impacts

Through this project, Balisi trained two female undergraduate interns on project design, data collection, statistical analysis, scientific writing, and presentation of results. Both interns have graduated; one earned a conference travel grant of her own and has come to manage a paleontological field school, while the other--having contributed to this project by making molds of carnivore teeth--now attends dentistry school.

In addition to the research itself, this grant supported Balisi's travel to conferences--e.g. Society of Vertebrate Paleontology (2015 in Dallas, TX; 2016 in Salt Lake City, UT), Society for Integrative and Comparative Biology (2016 in Portland, OR)--where she presented these results. This grant also funded Balisi's attendance at a workshop at the University of Utah, where she acquired stable isotope biogeochemistry techniques to address further research questions.

This grant aided Balisi's participation in outreach events at schools across Greater Los Angeles and Orange County. These are areas with many students who, like Balisi, are immigrants and/or people of color who may need role models in science with stories like theirs. Events included Jurassic Park Day at a Title I school to cap the school's reading of the Michael Crichton book and celebrate the reopening of a local park. Balisi's research presentation was attended by the town mayor: an opportunity to communicate the value of science with a local leader.

Considering the success of Jurassic Park, Ice Age, and the dire wolves of Game of Thrones, paleontology and paleobiology have become entrenched in popular culture. In this project, we have not only advanced the field of paleobiology but also leveraged its popularity to recruit a new generation of creative scientists, critical thinkers, and science enthusiasts from diverse perspectives?because having a diverse palette boosts the resilience of communities apart from dogs millions of years old.
